items.title: Engineers Bring Processes of Nature to Design
items.abstract: Morphogenesis, from the Greek words morphê, for shape and genesis, for creation, refers to imitating evolution in developing designs.

items.title: Is School Designed More for Girls Than Boys?
items.abstract: Have you noticed boys who are struggling in school because of poor behavior? Do you see boys who are “smart,” yet unengaged by school? More so than girls?

items.title: Suburban Perfection, With Warts
items.abstract: “The Playroom” is a drama about a seemingly ideal family in the 1970s that has several cracks below the surface.

items.title: The Extraordinary Science of Addictive Junk Food
items.abstract: Inside the hyperengineered, savagely marketed, addiction-creating battle for American “stomach share.”

items.title: Plan Would Let State Take Control of City’s Teacher Evaluation System
items.abstract: If Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and the teachers’ union can’t reach an agreement, the proposal allows the state to establish an evaluation system for New York City’s educators.

items.title: ‘The Geography of Genius,’ by Eric Weiner
items.abstract: A tour of some of the world’s exceptional places.
keywords: The Geography of Genius: A Search for the World's Most Creative Places From Ancient Athens to Silicon Valley (Book)

items.title: New York City’s Promising Step on Criminal Justice
items.abstract: A new bill could make many “quality of life” violations civil, not criminal, offenses, helping to ease the overpolicing in communities of color.

items.title: Buffalo in the City
items.abstract: Once an icon of masculinity, the plaid pattern has become an accidental camp classic.

items.title: Bloomberg’s Presidential Dreams, and Past Realities
items.abstract: Beyond the precedent set by the fate of previous independent presidential candidates, Michael R. Bloomberg would face other obvious obstacles on the road to the White House.

items.title: Review: ‘The Lonely City,’ a Personal Study of Urban Isolation
items.abstract: This Olivia Laing book is partly a memoir, partly a critic’s look into visual artists whose productions speak to her heartsick sense of solitude.
keywords: The Lonely City: Adventures in the Art of Being Alone (Book)

items.title: In High-Tech Cities, No More Potholes, but What About Privacy?
items.abstract: Cities, including some far from the coasts, are vying to use technology to guide services. But the race toward “smart cities” is raising privacy worries.

items.title: In a World of Fine Lines, Manchester City Tightens the Title Race
items.abstract: A game decided by the slightest of differences set the tone for a fierce battle for the Premier League between Liverpool and City (and perhaps Tottenham).

items.title: They Married at City Hall (But Didn’t Toss the Bouquet)
items.abstract: Three couples share their stories after marrying on a December day at the Manhattan Marriage Bureau, where the brides also rented their flowers.

items.title: Why De Blasio Loves ‘The Simpsons’ (and Where He’d Take Homer in New York City)
items.abstract: Before a cameo appearance on “The Simpsons" on Sunday, the New York City mayor spoke about his love for the show, his channel-surfing habits and why he is not bothered when shows he likes air on Fox.

items.title: An Indian City Bursting With Action
items.abstract: The present-day version of Chennai in South India dates back to only the 1600s, so a relatively youthful exuberance should not come as a surprise.

items.title: How to Design a Home Gym That You’ll Actually Use
items.abstract: As the pandemic rages on, the safest place to work out is at home. Here’s how to create a personal gym you’ll want to spend time in.

items.title: New York Plans to Install ‘Vending Machines’ With Anti-Overdose Drugs
items.abstract: In addition to naloxone, a medication used to reverse opioid overdoses, the machines will distribute free syringes, toiletries and safe-sex kits.

items.title: Documenting Los Angeles’s Unlikely Urban Fishermen
items.abstract: The act of fishing in Los Angeles seems almost defiant: a tranquil outdoors activity against a backdrop of concrete, litter and highway overpasses.

items.title: If Rover Can Make It Here, Perhaps Bald Eagles Can Make It Anywhere
items.abstract: A white-headed raptor has been preying on smaller birds in Central Park. It’s come a long way since conservationists affixed aluminum bands to its legs four years ago.

items.title: Celebrating Black History Month? These 5 Cities Are Going All Out
items.abstract: Honoring all things African-American, with performances, river cruises, exhibitions and more, in Richmond, Va., Portland, Ore., Philadelphia, Cleveland and San Antonio.
